ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The main skill I learned from this class is being able to authentically close read complex readings. I learned how to break down sentences into smaller parts to better understand what was being said. I also became better at defining the words I used in my writing.

I learned how to truly analyze texts and got to read the most incredible selection. I also learned about Indigenous cosmologies and epistemologies, as well as place-thought. This course offered a diverse perspective.

I learned a lot about the ways climate change narratives are created and manipulated to benefit those in power and how human interactions are inseparable from the land they take place on and around. I also got better at drafting and revising my writing to clarify my arguments.

During this course, I learned about the epistemological and ontological divide within academia due to colonialism. Additionally, throughout the course, we reviewed literature from scholars who, if left to the "great tradition/dominant group," would remain unheard. We explored the discourse and disconnection in the context of environmental justice, spirituality, race, capitalism, and colonialism. We were also given the academic space to research and pursue our interests.  The skills, insights, and knowledge I feel I have personally acquired are those needed to dismantle such forces in pursuit of collective and global understanding.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The topics covered are very interesting; deadlines are lenient which reduces stress.
Weakness: Seminar can drag a bit if students are not in the mood for class (class is what students make of it which can be good and bad)
This course was INCREDIBLE and Rasheed is the best professor- chooses the most amazing texts and selections and is very flexible with due dates.

The course content is fascinating, relevant, and easy to connect to on a personal level. The professor was genuinely interested in each one of us as people, and the discussion-based format of the class lended itself to that. The cultural diversity of the class was such a strength, especially for the type of material we were covering. Personal stories from my classmates contributed to my understanding throughout the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. It is low stress and involves very important and easy topics.
YES!!! Rasheed is the best professor and could not recommend a course more. His feedback is amazing and so beyond helpful. The texts are also so incredibly engaging and great!

I would recommend this course because it allows you to see the other side of the coin, or in this case, the voices that have been suppressed due to colonialism. This course will change your understanding of the generational effects colonialism has had on the world.
